title: One hard and one easy?
content:
2 fonts I am having a hard time looking for. Much appreciated for your help or comment.

- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - —— - - - — - - - - - -  
1. Modern San serif

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20081011053209im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/1_3695.jpg)

- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - —— - - - — - - - - - -  
2. Classic bold san serif. I love the W and the inverted comma.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20081011053209im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/2_5780.jpg)

 [‹ two id's](http://web.archive.org/web/20081011053209/http:/www.typophile.com/node/45096 "Go to previous forum topic") [washup ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20081011053209/http:/www.typophile.com/node/45099 "Go to next forum topic")
author: kidcranium

comments.content: Well, the latter one is currently ubiquitous Avant Garde Gothic, alternative W.

Avant garde seems to be the only one I always manage to ID.

[http://www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/elsner\_flake/avant\_garde\_gothic\_...](http://web.archive.org/web/20081011053209/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/elsner_flake/avant_garde_gothic_alternate_ot/ "http://www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/elsner\_flake/avant\_garde\_gothic\_alternate\_ot/")
I still wonder how one can have a hard time looking for Avant Garde.
Thanks everyone for your help. I didn’t know Avant Garde “W” can look so elegant in bold type. Yeah it seems like a no brainer to id, sorry for my type ignorance.
